SENT.plain: Fifty six patients aged 17 to 45 years who had Ischemic Cerebral Infarction (I.C.I.) were studied
Cerebral embolism either from cardiac (10 patients) and from unknown source (3 patients); 3
Traumas of skull and neck (3 patients); 6
In 6 cases the etiology remained unknown
Young subjects with I.C.I. are a heterogeneous group: however in most of them a reasonable cause can be found
The occurrence of acute death (14%) was high, while recurrent stroke (5%) and non acute death (3%) were rare when compared to older patients
At the follow-up 80% had a very little residual motor deficit but only 43% were able to return to previous work
